comment.author: 40089693@N07
comment._content: It looks as though the only native Irish in this picture is the woman on the far right... am I right by this observation and if so where do you think the other women are from?

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: How can you answer an observation like Guiseppe's?  Can anyone tell the nationality of a person from a 100 year old photograph?  While Ireland would have had less of an ethnic mix in the early 1900's than most European countries none the less the island was invaded several times with additions to the gene pool as a result.  There was a certain amount of immigration by Spanish, French, Scandinavians, Dutch, English, Welsh, Scots and Germans to name a few. Having said that I know people who look just like the ladies in the shot who bear names like O'Brien, Ryan, MacNamara etc.  In those days as well these ladies would have spent a great deal of their time out of doors with no creams and make-up to protect their complexions.  Interesting observation all the same.

comment.author: 22584609@N02
comment._content: ;D

comment.author: 20957793@N05
comment._content: According to Peadar O'Dowd's book "Down by the Claddagh", this image was used as a postcard which was printed in Berlin. It shows four women "making their way up along Long Walk to the fish market in front of the Spanish Arch." The whitewashed houses of the Claddagh are visible in the background.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/20957793@N05] Thank you. We have a copy of that book here at Library Towers. I'll have to look at it. Added your info to the description above...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
